case_name: Revenue v. South India Bank Limited

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 842 of 1964 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal No. 842 of 1964. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated February 19, 1963 of the Kerala High Court in Income- tax Referred Case No. 23 of 1962.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated February 19, 1963 of Kerala High Court in Income-tax Referred Case No. 23 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated February 19, 1963 of the Kerala High Court in Income- tax Referred Case No. 23 of 1962.

facts.text: Respondent is South India Bank Limited, Trichur, a banking company.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent, the South India Bank Limited, Trichur, is a banking companypany.

facts.text: Appeal concerned with assessment year 1956-57, corresponding previous year calendar year 1955.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal is companycerned with the assessment year 1956-57, companyresponding previous year being the calendar year 1955.

facts.text: During accounting year, Bank received Rs. 44,720/- towards interest on tax-free Cochin and Travancore Securities.

anchor.surface_text: During the accounting year the Bank received a sum of Rs. 44,720/- towards interest in respect of taxfree Cochin and Travancore Securities.

facts.text: Assessee claimed rebate on entire Rs. 44,720/- received as interest from the securities.

anchor.surface_text: During the companyrse of the assessment of its income to tax, it claimed that rebate should be allowed on the entire sum of Rs. 44,720/- received as interest from the said securities.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer arrived at Rs. 33,444/- as sum for reasonable expenditure in realizing interest and interest on borrowed money for investment.

anchor.surface_text: But, the Income-tax Officer, while companypleting the assessment, arrived at the figure of Rs. 33,444/- as the sum representing two items, viz.,  i  reasonable sum expended by the assessee in realizing the said interest and  ii  the interest payable on the money borrowed for the purpose of investment.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer granted rebate of Rs. 7,276/- after deducting Rs. 33,444/- from interest receivable.

anchor.surface_text: After deducting the said sum from the interest receivable from the said securities, he granted only a sum of Rs. 7,276/- as rebate for income-tax.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner upheld Income-tax Officer's view.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal, the Appellate Assistant Commissioner upheld the view of the Income-tax Officer.

facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal held Bank entitled to rebate on gross amount of Rs. 44,720/-

anchor.surface_text: On a further appeal, the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal, Madras Bench, held that the Bank was entitled to a, rebate on the gross amount of interest amounting to Rs. 44,720/-

facts.text: Department requested Tribunal to refer question to Kerala High Court.

anchor.surface_text: At the instance of the Department, the Tribunal referred the following question to the High Court of Kerala for its decision

facts.text: Kerala High Court Division Bench held entire interest of Rs. 44,720/- entitled to rebate under notification by Central Government under s. 60-A.

anchor.surface_text: A Division Bench of the High Court expressed the opinion that the entire interest of Rs. 44,720/- was entitled to rebate for income-tax under the numberification issued by the Central Government in exercise of its powers under s. 60-A of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922.

facts.text: Notification exempts income-tax on interest receivable on tax-free loans issued by former Governments of Travancore or Cochin, if received within Travancore-Cochin territories and not brought elsewhere.

anchor.surface_text: No income-tax shall be payable by an assessee on the interest receivable on the following income-tax free loans issued by the former Government of Travancore or by the former Government of Cochin, provided that such interest is received within the territories of the State of Travancore-Cochin and is number brought into any other part of the taxable territories to which the said Act applies.

facts.text: Notification includes exempted interest in total income for purposes of Section 16.

anchor.surface_text: Such interest shall, however, be included in the total income of the assessee for the purposes of Section 16 of the Indian Income- tax Act, 1922

facts.text: It is common case that notification applies to the securities in question.

anchor.surface_text: It is companymon case that this numberification applies to the securities in question.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds no income-tax payable on entire interest of Rs. 44,720/- earned by assessee from securities issued by former native States.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, hold, agreeing with the High Court, that numberincome-tax is payable in respect of the entire interest of Rs. 44,720/- earned by the assessee from securities issued by the former native States.

facts.text: Securities issued by former Governments of Cochin and Travancore.

anchor.surface_text: taxfree Cochin and Travancore Securities.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by Subba Rao, J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Subba Rao, J.

facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal is Madras Bench.

anchor.surface_text: the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal, Madras Bench,

facts.text: Interest received within territories of State of Travancore-Cochin and not brought into other taxable territories.

anchor.surface_text: provided that such interest is received within the territories of the State of Travancore-Cochin and is number brought into any other part of the taxable territories to which the said Act applies.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated February 19, 1963 of the Kerala High Court in Income- tax Referred Case No. 23 of 1962.

At the instance of the Department, the Tribunal referred the following question to the High Court of Kerala for its decision Whether, on the facts and circumstances of the case, the Tribunal was right in holding that Explanation to section 8 is not applicable in this case and that the entire interest of Rs. 44,720/- earned by the assessee from securities issued by the former Native States, etc. is entitled to rebate of income-tax.

issues.text: Whether, on the facts and circumstances of the case, the Tribunal was right in holding that Explanation to section 8 is not applicable in this case and that the entire interest of Rs. 44,720/- earned by the assessee from securities issued by the former Native States, etc. is entitled to rebate of income-tax.

anchor.surface_text: At the instance of the Department, the Tribunal referred the following question to the High Court of Kerala for its decision Whether, on the facts and circumstances of the case, the Tribunal was right in holding that Explanation to section 8 is not applicable in this case and that the entire interest of Rs. 44,720/- earned by the assessee from securities issued by the former Native States, etc. is entitled to rebate of income-tax.

issues.text: Whether the notification issued by the Central Government under s. 60A of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922 entitles the entire interest of Rs. 44,720/- to rebate for income-tax.

anchor.surface_text: A Division Bench of the High Court expressed the opinion that the entire interest of Rs. 44,720/- was entitled to rebate for income-tax under the notification issued by the Central Government in exercise of its powers under s. 60-A of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922.

issues.text: Whether the notification under s. 60A is to be construed on its own terms independently of s. 8 of the Income-tax Act or must be read in terms of s. 8.

anchor.surface_text: Section 60 of the Act confers a power on the Central Government to make an exemption, reduction in rate, or other modifications in respect of income-tax in favour of any class of income or in regard to the whole or any part of any income of any class of persons.

issues.text: Whether the expression 'interest receivable on income-tax free loans' in the notification means the gross interest as per terms of securities or net of realization expenses and borrowed money interest.

anchor.surface_text: The expression interest receivable on income-tax free loans is clear and unambiguous. Though the point of time from which the exemption works is when it is received within the territories of the State of Travancore-Cochin, what is exempted is the interest receivable.

arguments.claim: Under s. 8 of the Indian Income-tax Act, income-tax was computed under the head interest on securities in respect of the interest received minus expenditure to realise per first proviso and Explanation

anchor.surface_text: Mr. R. Ganapathy Iyer, learned counsel for the Revenue, argued that under s. 8 of the Indian Income-tax Act, income- tax was computed under the head interest on securities in respect of the interest received by an assessee on any government securities minus the expenditure incurred by him to realise the same in terms of the first proviso and the Explanation thereto

arguments.claim: Under the third proviso to s.8, assessee exempted only from tax payable on interest receivable on income-tax free State Government securities if not exempted, i.e., only on net taxable amount

anchor.surface_text: , that when under the third proviso the assessee was exempted from paying tax on the interest receivable on any securities of State Government issued income-tax free, he was only exempted from such tax payable by him if it was not so exempted.

arguments.claim: Notification under s.60A does not enlarge exemption scope but must be construed only in terms of s.8

anchor.surface_text: His further contention was that the notification issued by the Central Government under s. 60A of the Income- tax Act did not enlarge the scope of the exemption but that the said notification must be construed only in terms of S. 8 of the Income-tax Act.

arguments.court_reasoning: Notification is self-contained, issued de hors s.8 under special power, no reference to s.8, no redundancy

arguments.claim: Substantive part of s.8 read with first proviso and Explanation has no application to securities issued income-tax free

anchor.surface_text: Mr. A. V. Viswanatha Sastri, learned counsel for the respondent, argued that the substantive part of S. 8, read with the first proviso and the Explanation thereto, had no application to securities issued income-tax free

arguments.court_reasoning: Agreed with High Court; notification self-contained exempting gross interest receivable

arguments.claim: Do not propose to express opinion on rival contentions on s.8 as agree with High Court on notification construction

anchor.surface_text: As we agree with the High Court on the construction of the notification issued by the Central Government, we do not propose to express our opinion on the rival contentions of the parties based upon the provisions of s. 8 of the Income- tax Act.

arguments.claim: S.60 confers power on Central Government for exemption etc. de hors s.8 to meet special situations

anchor.surface_text: Section 60 of the Act confers a power on the Central Government to make an exemption, reduction in rate, or other modifications in respect of income-tax in favour of any class of income or in regard to the whole or any part of any income of any class of persons.

arguments.claim: No scope to invoke s.60A power if s.8 already provides exemption; notification not redundant or superabundant caution

anchor.surface_text: This power is conferred on the Government to meet special situations de hors s. 8. If s. 8 of the Income- tax Act makes an exemption in respect of a particular income, there is no scope or occasion for invoking the special power conferred on the Central Government under S. 60A of the Income-tax Act.

arguments.claim: Notification to be construed on its own terms without reference to s.8

anchor.surface_text: Unless we accept the contention that the notification under S. 60A was issued by the Central Government in superabundant caution to cover the same ground occupied by s. 8-we need not attribute any such redundancy to the Central Government-we do not see any reason why the notification should not be construed on its own terms

arguments.claim: Notification self-contained: total exemption on interest receivable on specified tax-free loans subject to receipt conditions; no reference to s.8

anchor.surface_text: It will be noticed that this notification does not refer to the provisions of s. 8 of the Income-tax Act at all. It gives a total exemption from income-tax to an assessee in respect of the interest receivable on Income-tax free loans mentioned therein. It gives that exemption subject to two conditions, namely, (i) that the interest is received

arguments.claim: 'Interest receivable on income-tax free loans' clear and unambiguous: means gross amount per terms of securities, not net of expenses

holdings.text: The notification under S. 60A was not issued in superabundant caution but should be construed on its own terms without reference to s. 8.

anchor.surface_text: Unless we accept the contention that the notification under S. 60A was issued by the Central Government in superabundant caution to cover the same ground occupied by s. 8-we need not attribute any such redundancy to the Central Government-we do not see any reason why the notification should not be construed on its own terms

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.60A confers special power de hors s.8 for exemptions; assuming redundancy would be improper; notification self-contained without mentioning s.8.

holdings.text: The notification is self-contained, providing total exemption from income-tax on interest receivable on specified tax-free loans subject to conditions of receipt within Travancore-Cochin and not exported.

anchor.surface_text: It will be noticed that this notification does not refer to the provisions of s. 8 of the Income-tax Act at all. It gives a total exemption from income-tax to an assessee in respect of the interest receivable on Income-tax free loans mentioned therein. It gives that exemption subject to two conditions, namely, (i) that the interest is received

holdings.reasoning_summary: Notification text independent of s.8; specifies exemption on 'interest receivable' with conditions; includes in total income u/s.16; no scope to control by s.8.

holdings.text: The expression 'interest receivable on income-tax free loans' is clear and unambiguous, meaning the gross amount calculated as per the terms of the securities, not net of realization expenses.

anchor.surface_text: The expression interest receivable on income-tax free loans is clear and unambiguous. Though the point of time from which the exemption works is when it is received within the territories of the State of Travancore-Cochin, what is exempted is the interest receivable. Interest receivable can only mean the amount of interest calculated as per the terms of the securities.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain language exempts 'interest receivable'; exemption effective on receipt but covers full receivable amount; no basis to deduct expenses not mentioned.

holdings.text: No income-tax is payable in respect of the entire interest of Rs. 44,720/- earned by the assessee from securities issued by the former native States.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, hold, agreeing with the High Court, that no income-tax is payable in respect of the entire interest of Rs. 44,720/- earned by the assessee from securities issued by the former native States.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Notification applies to securities; construed independently exempts gross interest; agrees with High Court and Tribunal.

holdings.text: The Tribunal was right in holding that the entire interest of Rs. 44,720/- is entitled to rebate of income-tax under the notification.

anchor.surface_text: A Division Bench of the High Court expressed the opinion that the entire interest of Rs. 44,720/- was entitled to rebate for income-tax under the notification issued by the Central Government in exercise of its powers under s. 60-A of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agrees with High Court construction of notification entitling full rebate; resolves referred question affirmatively.

anchor.surface_text: It will be noticed that this notification does not refer to the provisions of s. 8 of the Income-tax Act at all. It gives a total exemption from income-tax to an assessee in respect of the interest receivable on Income-tax free loans mentioned therein. It gives that exemption subject to two conditions, namely, (i) that the interest is received

anchor.surface_text: The expression interest receivable on income-tax free loans is clear and unambiguous. Though the point of time from which the exemption works is when it is received within the territories of the State of Travancore-Cochin, what is exempted is the interest receivable. Interest receivable can only mean the amount of interest calculated as per the terms of the securities.

We, therefore, hold, agreeing with the High Court, that no income-tax is payable in respect of the entire interest of Rs. 44,720/- earned by the assessee from securities issued by the former native States.

anchor.surface_text: A Division Bench of the High Court expressed the opinion that the entire interest of Rs. 44,720/- was entitled to rebate for income-tax under the notification issued by the Central Government in exercise of its powers under s. 60-A of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922.

We, therefore, hold, agreeing with the High Court, that no income-tax is payable in respect of the entire interest of Rs. 44,720/- earned by the assessee from securities issued by the former native States.
